awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: 3D Scanning Tool for Reconstruction Via Uncertainty Quantification
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of an interactive 3D scanning tool that targets novice users.   The goal of the proposed technology is to bridge 3D reconstruction via 3D scanners, which typically require extensive expertise, to novice users with no background in geometry processing. 3D scanners generate depth scans that are partial surfaces of the underlying object. A 3D reconstruction typically requires registering depth scans under different camera poses, known as the registration procedure, and reconstructing a complete surface from the registered scans, known as surface reconstruction. The performance of registration heavily depends on the structure of how scans overlap with each other.  The proposed technology uses a principled uncertainty quantification framework that may accurately predict the uncertainties of 3D reconstruction from depth scans. It was determined that the predicted uncertainties provide an effective means to guide scan planning that minimizes the number of scans and improves reconstruction quality.  This technology may reduce the 3D acquisition time and improve the reconstruction quality. Applications include reconstructions of human teeth for dentists to perform surgery planning, reconstructions of buildings, bridges, and other architectural artifacts for damage inspection, 3D reconstructions of traffic accidents for crime analysis, and 3D reconstructions of mechanical parts for model checking. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of uncertainty quantification algorithms for multi-scan registration and reconstruction and view planning algorithms based on quantified uncertainties. The proposed technology is designed for quantifying the uncertainties of the current 3D reconstruction, automating reconstruction completeness checking, online scan planning to reduce the uncertainties of reconstruction, enhancing completeness, and minimizing scanning time. The goal is to integrate the proposed technology into existing software packages for 3D reconstruction, making them easy to use for novice users with no background in geometry processing. The proposed technology addresses the limitations of existing scan-based 3D reconstruction techniques, especially the long acquisition period and the lack of effective reconstruction quality assessment methods, problems that have been well-documented in the research literature. Research findings examining the proposed technology suggest that efficient uncertainty quantification techniques may enhance the quality of 3D reconstruction and reduce scanning time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of participating in the I-Corps program was to find a commercialization pathway for our uncertainty quantification technique for interactive 3D reconstruction, in which the quantified uncertainties provide users with direct assessments of current reconstructions and how to acquire more data to improve the reconstruction. We started the program with the aim of developing a new software package for interactive 3D teeth reconstruction in the dental industry. We believe that our technique can significantly improve the user experience of dentists in terms of shorter acquisition times and more accurate reconstructions. The reduced acquisition time is also of great interest for patients. After conducting initial interviews with dentists, we found that there are barriers when applying our technique in the dental industry. One major factor is that all interactive tooth acquisition devices are accompanied by their own software packages, which do not have simple interfaces to incorporate additional functionalities. While we keep the path to the dental industry open, we started to focus on identifying an appropriate business model for our technique and the easiest application venues. Due to the popularity of mobile phones and associated depth sensors, we find that there is potential to develop a mobile application that integrates our technique. During our interviews, we focused on potential applications of this online application. We also studied another path of developing a website that allows users to update data for 3D reconstruction. This targets potential avenues for large-scale 3D reconstruction that are beyond the scope of mobile sensors. 

During the I-Corps program, we conducted more than 60 interviews in the mobile application industry to understand the business model of a mobile interactive 3D reconstruction application enabled by our uncertainty quantification approach. The following are the key outcomes of the I-Corps program,

1. Understood the customer discovery process by conducting more than 120 interviews with potential customers, partners, and vendors.

2. Validated the value propositions and customer segment for the mobile 3D interactive reconstruction through customer discovery.

3. Received positive feedbacks from various companies who develop mobile applications for virtual reality and augmented reality acknowledging the need for such a mobile application.

In addition to developing a mobile application, we have also explored commercializing our technology by developing a website on which users submit data and it then performs 3D reconstruction and uncertainty quantification. We attended the following conferences in which the large-scale 3D reconstruction industry is well represented. 

1. IEEE Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR) 2023,

2. Special Interest Group on Computer Graphics and Interactive Techniques (SIGGRAPH) 2023.

These 3D reconstruction related conferences allowed us to understand the competitive landscape and explore the potential of the online website. We connected with a few large companies who showed interest in utilizing our website.

In the deep learning era, where most inverse problems are approaches using deep neural networks, our interviews have also focused on how such a non-deep learning based approach can succeed against deep learning based counterparts.


Last Modified: 07/21/2024
Modified by: Qixing Huang
